channel.title: Reconnaissance on TLDRBins
channel.description: Recent content in Reconnaissance on TLDRBins

item.title: DNS Enum
item.description: Linux Windows Zone Transfer dig +noall +answer <DOMAIN> axfr @<TARGET> $ dig +noall +answer snoopy.htb axfr @10.10.11.212 snoopy.htb. 86400 IN SOA ns1.snoopy.htb. ns2.snoopy.htb. 2022032612 3600 1800 604800 86400 snoopy.htb. 86400 IN NS ns1.snoopy.htb. snoopy.htb. 86400 IN NS ns2.snoopy.htb. mattermost.snoopy.htb. 86400 IN A 172.18.0.3 mm.snoopy.htb. 86400 IN A 127.0.0.1 ns1.snoopy.htb. 86400 IN A 10.0.50.10 ns2.snoopy.htb. 86400 IN A 10.0.51.10 postgres.snoopy.htb. 86400 IN A 172.18.0.2 provisions.snoopy.htb. 86400 IN A 172.18.0.4 www.snoopy.htb. 86400 IN A 127.

item.title: Drupal
item.description: Enum droopescan droopescan scan drupal -u <TARGET> Ref: droopescan Note: This can take a long time to run

item.title: Network Discovery
item.description: Test connectivity Linux Windows # Default infinite pings ping -c3 <TARGET> # Default 5 pings ping <TARGET> # Check specific port Test-NetConnection <TARGET> -Port <TARGET_PORT> Test reverse connectivity Linux sudo tcpdump -ni tun0 icmp Sniff network traffic Linux # Sniff on network adapter sudo tcpdump -i eth0 -w packets.pcap root@NIX01:/dev/shm# sudo tcpdump -i eth0 -w packets.pcap tcpdump: listening on eth0, link-type EN10MB (Ethernet), capture size 262144 bytes ^C124 packets captured <----- Send Ctrl+C after some time 133 packets received by filter 0 packets dropped by kernel # For example: on port 389 sudo tcpdump -i lo -nnXs 0 'port <TARGET_PORT>' # Sniff HTTPS traffic sudo .

item.title: Nmap
item.description: Nmap Scan TCP UDP Script target=<TARGET> nmap -p- --min-rate 10000 -oA ./nmap-alltcp $target ports=$(cat nmap-alltcp.nmap| grep -Eo "^[0-9]+" | tr '\n' ',' | sed -r 's/,$//') nmap -p $ports -sCV -oA ./nmap-tcpscripts $target target=<TARGET> nmap -sU --min-rate 10000 -oA ./nmap-udp $target ports=$(cat nmap-udp.nmap| grep -Eo "^[0-9]+" | tr '\n' ',' | sed -r 's/,$//') nmap -p $ports -sU -sCV -oA ./nmap-udpscripts $target Update scripts DB nmap --script-updatedb Search scripts # e.

item.title: SMB Enum
item.description: SMB Share Enum nmap sudo nmap --script=smb-enum-shares -p 445 <TARGET> $ sudo nmap --script=smb-enum-shares -p 445 10.10.11.207 Starting Nmap 7.94SVN ( https://nmap.org ) at 2024-09-25 04:53 GMT Nmap scan report for 10.10.11.207 Host is up (0.26s latency). PORT STATE SERVICE 445/tcp open microsoft-ds Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 7.96 seconds Anonymous Login smbmap smbclient impacket smbmap -H <TARGET> --no-banner smbmap -H <TARGET> -u null --no-banner # List known share smbmap -H <TARGET> -r <SHARE> smbclient -N -L \\\\<TARGET>\\ $ smbclient -N -L \\\\10.

item.title: SNMP
item.description: Bruteforce commmuity string onesixtyone snmpbrute # Brute force community string for snmpwalk use onesixtyone <TARGET> -c /usr/share/doc/onesixtyone/dict.txt $ onesixtyone 10.10.11.248 -c /usr/share/doc/onesixtyone/dict.txt Scanning 1 hosts, 50 communities 10.10.11.248 [public] Linux monitored 5.10.0-28-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 5.10.209-2 (2024-01-31) x86_64 Ref: onesixtyone # Brute force community string (Check also SNMPv2) python3 snmpbrute.py -t <TARGET> $ python3 snmpbrute.py -t 10.10.11.248 _____ _ ____ _______ ____ __ / ___// | / / |/ / __ \ / __ )_______ __/ /____ \__ \/ |/ / /|_/ / /_/ / / __ / ___/ / / / __/ _ \ ___/ / /| / / / / ____/ / /_/ / / / /_/ / /_/ __/ /____/_/ |_/_/ /_/_/ /_____/_/ \__,_/\__/\___/ SNMP Bruteforce & Enumeration Script v2.

item.title: SSL
item.description: Tools sslscan # Scan target SSL version sslscan <TARGET> Fix old ssl protocol connection problem # Edit /etc/ssl/openssl.cnf [system_default_sect] #MinProtocol = DEFAULT@SECLEVEL=2 MinProtocol = None #CipherString = DEFAULT@SECLEVEL=2 CipherString = None Note: Remember to revert the changes after job done

item.title: Subdomain Enum
item.description: Add domain/subdomain to /etc/hosts echo "<TARGET_IP> <DOMAIN>" | sudo tee -a /etc/hosts wfuzz gobuster wfuzz -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/DNS/bitquark-subdomains-top100000.txt -H "Host: FUZZ.<DOMAIN>" -u <TARGET> Take note of the word size, Ctrl+C to interrupt the process, then run again wfuzz -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/DNS/bitquark-subdomains-top100000.txt -H "Host: FUZZ.<DOMAIN>" -u <TARGET> --hw <WORD> Filter out response with header # For example: Access-Control-Allow-Origin wfuzz -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/DNS/bitquark-subdomains-top100000.txt -H "Origin: http://FUZZ.<DOMAIN>" --filter "r.headers.response ~ 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin'" -u <TARGET> gobuster vhost -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/DNS/bitquark-subdomains-top100000.

item.title: Web Directory Enum
item.description: feroxbuster wfuzz gobuster bfac ds_walk HTTP feroxbuster -u <TARGET> --depth 1 --methods=GET,POST -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/Web-Content/raft-medium-directories.txt --dont-extract-links HTTPS feroxbuster -u <TARGET> -k --depth 1 --methods=GET,POST -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/Web-Content/raft-medium-directories.txt --dont-extract-links Specify Extension feroxbuster -u <TARGET> --methods=GET,POST --depth=1 -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/Web-Content/raft-medium-words.txt -x html, asp, aspx Add trailing slash '/' to each request feroxbuster -u <TARGET> -f --depth 1 --methods=GET,POST -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/Web-Content/raft-medium-directories.txt API Fuzzing feroxbuster -u <TARGET> --force-recursion -C 404,405 --methods=GET,POST -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/Web-Content/raft-medium-directories.txt Fuzzing Number Range wfuzz -z range,1-99 <TARGET>/FUZZ gobuster dir -u <TARGET> -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/Web-Content/raft-medium-words.

item.title: whois
item.description: WHOIS # General whois <DOMAIN> # With specific server whois -h <WHOIS_SERVER> -p 43 <DOMAIN>

item.title: Wordpress
item.description: Default config location /var/www/html/wp-config.php Tools wpscan # HTTP wpscan --url <TARGET> -e ap,t,tt,u # HTTPS wpscan --url <TARGET> -e ap,t,tt,u --disable-tls-checks # You will need an api token to scan vulns wpscan --url <TARGET> -e ap,t,tt,u --api-token <API_KEY> # Brute force wp-admin wpscan --url <TARGET> --passwords passwords.txt --usernames admin Ref: Get Free API key
